questiontext.text: In the Monsanto acetic acid process (Rh-catalyzed carbonylation), the catalytic cycle explicitly features which paired elementary steps as highlighted in the syllabus outline?

generalfeedback.text: The Monsanto process is presented as a Rh-based carbonylation cycle in which oxidative addition and CO insertion are key elementary organometallic steps used to build the acyl functionality leading to acetic acid. Oxidative addition is consistent with increasing metal oxidation state/coordination number and is one of the named elementary reactions emphasized for catalytic cycles in organometallic chemistry. CO migratory insertion is the characteristic step that converts a metal–alkyl (or related) bond into a metal–acyl linkage, which aligns with carbonylation chemistry. β-hydride elimination is discussed in the context of metal–alkyl stability and is central to some oxidation/hydride chemistry, but it is not the defining pair of steps highlighted for Monsanto carbonylation in the provided outline. Purely radical abstraction or “ligand rotation only” does not capture the named mechanistic framework of oxidative addition/insertion used in organometallic catalytic cycles.

answer.text: Oxidative addition followed by CO migratory insertion
Reductive elimination followed by β-hydride elimination
σ-bond metathesis followed by radical abstraction
Associative substitution followed by ligand rotation only

questiontext.text: Olefin metathesis is taught as proceeding through metal–carbene intermediates, and the syllabus explicitly contrasts Grubbs and Schrock catalysts. Which statement best matches the mechanistic implication of this emphasis?

generalfeedback.text: The outline explicitly connects metathesis to metal–carbene complexes and names Grubbs and Schrock catalysts, which signals that a metal–carbene intermediate is central to C=C bond rearrangement. This framing distinguishes metathesis from catalytic manifolds dominated by oxidative addition/reductive elimination at a metal center acting mainly on σ-bonds. β-hydride elimination is an important elementary step for metal–alkyl complexes, but it does not explain the hallmark exchange of alkylidene fragments and redistribution of C=C bonds in metathesis. The syllabus places metathesis under homogeneous catalysis topics, so “must be heterogeneous” is inconsistent with the stated categorization. Denying metal–carbon bond formation contradicts the stated involvement of metal–carbene species, which are defined by strong metal–carbon multiple-bond character.

answer.text: The key bond reorganization involves a metal–carbene-mediated interchange of C=C fragments rather than a simple oxidative addition/reductive elimination pair on a saturated alkyl.
The key step is always β-hydride elimination from a metal–alkyl to generate the new alkene distribution.
The catalyst must be heterogeneous and surface-bound for metathesis to occur.
Metathesis proceeds without any metal–carbon bond formation at any point in the cycle.

questiontext.text: \(\mathrm{Fe(CO)_5}\) is listed as a classic example in the fluxionality section. Which interpretation best explains why room-temperature NMR can show fewer distinct CO environments than expected from a static trigonal-bipyramidal structure?

generalfeedback.text: The fluxionality topic is defined as dynamic intramolecular rearrangement observable by NMR, and \(\mathrm{Fe(CO)_5}\) is specifically listed as a representative example. When exchange is fast relative to the NMR timescale, nuclei in distinct sites become time-averaged, giving fewer signals and often a single averaged resonance set at sufficiently high temperature. Permanent dissociation/reassociation would imply a different chemical speciation rather than classic fluxional averaging and is not required to explain the NMR behavior emphasized in the fluxionality section. Diamagnetism changes do not inherently collapse inequivalent-site resonances into one unless an exchange process averages them, and the provided framework points to dynamics rather than spin-state switching. IR selection rules govern vibrational transitions and do not directly force NMR coalescence, which is tied to chemical exchange kinetics and coalescence behavior described in the NMR-focused fluxionality content.

answer.text: Rapid intramolecular rearrangement exchanges axial and equatorial positions on the NMR timescale, averaging environments.
CO ligands permanently dissociate and reassociate, changing the molecular formula during measurement.
The complex becomes diamagnetic only at high temperature, which collapses peaks by changing spin state.
IR spectroscopy selection rules directly force NMR signals to merge.

questiontext.text: Hydroformylation is emphasized with “linear vs branched aldehydes” and “ligand effects on selectivity and activity.” Which statement best captures how ligand choice is used mechanistically in such a catalytic cycle?

generalfeedback.text: The hydroformylation learning objectives explicitly connect regioselectivity (linear vs branched aldehydes) with ligand effects on selectivity and activity, implying ligands control key coordination and insertion steps in the catalytic cycle. In organometallic reaction language, such control is naturally discussed in terms of how ligands affect binding modes, migratory insertion preferences, and the relative rates of competing pathways. Treating ligands as merely cosmetic contradicts the stated focus on ligand effects as a conceptual learning point. Hydroformylation is categorized under homogeneous catalysis in the outline, so attributing selectivity primarily to heterogeneous surface growth conflicts with the given context. CO is a core reagent in hydroformylation as presented in the mechanism-focused section headings, so claiming ligands remove the need for CO misrepresents the process emphasis.

answer.text: Ligands tune the steric/electronic environment at the metal to bias alkene coordination/insertion pathways, shifting the linear-to-branched aldehyde ratio.
Ligands only change the color of the catalyst solution and do not affect regioselectivity.
Ligands enforce heterogeneous surface growth, which is the primary cause of linear selectivity.
Ligands eliminate the need for CO in hydroformylation by generating CO in situ from the alkene.

questiontext.text: Ziegler–Natta polymerization is presented with “olefin insertion into Ti–carbon bond,” “coordination control,” and “tacticity control.” Which statement best integrates these ideas into a mechanistic rationale for stereospecificity?

generalfeedback.text: The outline explicitly ties stereospecific polymerization to olefin insertion into a Ti–C bond and highlights coordination control and tacticity, which together indicate that active-site geometry governs monomer approach and orientation during each insertion step. This is a direct mechanism-level explanation for how isotactic, syndiotactic, or atactic outcomes can arise from catalyst-controlled propagation rather than from post-processing. Monomer optical activity is not required for tacticity control in the framework presented, because the focus is on catalyst-based stereocontrol at coordination/insertion. Thermal annealing can change crystallinity and morphology, but it cannot retroactively impose a stereochemical sequence that was not created during chain propagation. The text emphasizes an insertion mechanism at a transition-metal center rather than free-radical chain growth, so a purely radical pathway contradicts the stated mechanistic focus. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/eecdaa56-93b9-4e87-bc04-9974af604151/inorganic_unit_07.txt)

answer.text: A chiral or stereoregulating environment at the active site controls how the alkene coordinates before repeated insertions into the metal–carbon bond, producing tactic polymers.
Stereospecificity arises mainly because the monomer is optically active, independent of the catalyst.
Tacticity is determined after polymerization by thermal annealing, not during chain growth.
The polymer grows by radical chain reactions in solution, so insertion into a metal–carbon bond is not involved.

questiontext.text: The 18-electron rule in organometallic chemistry is best stated as:

generalfeedback.text: The 18-electron rule is an electron-counting stability guideline stating that many stable transition-metal organometallic complexes achieve a total of 18 valence electrons at the metal center (metal electrons plus electrons donated by ligands). The +18 oxidation state idea is not chemically meaningful for these systems, and “18 d-electrons” confuses total valence electron count with only d-electrons. Stability is not determined by having 18 ligands; typical complexes have far fewer ligands and still satisfy (or violate) the 18-electron guideline depending on electron donation.

answer.text: Complexes are most stable when the metal valence shell has 18 electrons (metal + ligand donation), similar in spirit to the octet rule
Complexes are most stable when the metal oxidation state is +18
Complexes are most stable only when the metal has 18 d-electrons
Complexes are most stable when there are exactly 18 ligands around the metal

questiontext.text: The total valence electron count at Fe in Fe(CO)5 (neutral/covalent counting) is:

generalfeedback.text: In neutral counting, Fe contributes 8 valence electrons (group 8 metal), and each CO donates 2 electrons as an L-type ligand, so \(8 + 5\times 2 = 18\). Getting 16 usually comes from forgetting one CO donation or using an inconsistent counting method. Getting 20 typically results from double-counting ligand donation or incorrectly treating CO as a 4-electron donor. Getting 14 is a larger undercount that does not match the standard electron-counting approach for metal carbonyls.

questiontext.text: Stronger metal-to-CO π backbonding in a metal carbonyl typically causes the CO stretching frequency in IR to:

generalfeedback.text: π backbonding involves donation of electron density from metal dπ orbitals into the π* orbitals of CO, which weakens the internal C–O bond and lowers the IR stretching frequency. An increase in frequency would correspond to a stronger C–O bond, which is opposite to the effect of enhanced π backbonding. CO is not a spectator in metal carbonyls because backbonding strongly affects bonding and spectroscopy, and the CO stretch does not vanish simply due to coordination.

answer.text: Increase, because the C–O bond becomes stronger
Decrease, because the C–O bond order is reduced
Remain unchanged, because CO is a “spectator” ligand
Disappear completely, because CO becomes IR-inactive

questiontext.text: In organometallic notation, η5 (eta-five) hapticity for a cyclopentadienyl ligand most directly means:

generalfeedback.text: Hapticity (ηn) describes how many atoms of a π-bonded ligand are simultaneously coordinated to the metal, and η5 indicates coordination through five atoms (as in the Cp ring of metallocenes). It does not mean donation of five lone pairs, nor does it describe five different ligands making sigma bonds. Hapticity notation is not an oxidation-state label and does not fix the metal oxidation state to a particular value.

answer.text: The ligand binds through five contiguous atoms to the metal center
The ligand donates five lone pairs to the metal center
The ligand forms five separate sigma bonds from five different ligands
The ligand forces the metal to have oxidation state +5

questiontext.text: The Dewar–Chatt–Duncanson model for metal–olefin bonding emphasizes which combination of interactions?

generalfeedback.text: In the Dewar–Chatt–Duncanson description, an alkene donates electron density from its filled π orbital to the metal (σ-type interaction) and the metal can backdonate from d orbitals into the alkene π* orbital (π backbonding), stabilizing the complex. A purely ionic picture misses the key donor–acceptor orbital interactions used to explain bonding and reactivity in metal–olefin complexes. Omitting either the donation or backdonation half of the model gives an incomplete bonding description for many metal–olefin systems.

answer.text: σ donation from olefin to metal and π backdonation from metal to olefin π*
Purely ionic attraction between a positively charged metal and a negatively charged olefin
Only π donation from olefin to metal with no backbonding component
Only σ donation from metal to olefin with no donation from the olefin

questiontext.text: An alkyl ligand that is intrinsically incapable of undergoing β-hydride elimination (for structural reasons) is:

generalfeedback.text: β-hydride elimination requires at least one hydrogen on the β-carbon (the carbon adjacent to the metal-bound carbon), but a methyl group has no β-carbon at all, so the process cannot occur. Ethyl and isopropyl have β-hydrogens available, so β-hydride elimination is possible in principle. tert-Butyl has β-carbons (the methyl groups) bearing hydrogens, so it is not intrinsically forbidden by “no β-H,” even though steric and geometric factors may affect feasibility in real complexes.

answer.text: M–CH3 (metal–methyl)
M–CH2CH3 (metal–ethyl)
M–CH(CH3)2 (metal–isopropyl)
M–C(CH3)3 (metal–tert-butyl)

questiontext.text: A key characteristic more typical of Fischer-type metal carbenes (rather than Schrock-type) is:

generalfeedback.text: Fischer carbenes are commonly described as having an electrophilic carbene carbon and are often associated with features consistent with lower-valent, π-backbonding-capable metals and stabilizing substituents. The nucleophilic-carbene, early-metal, high-oxidation-state description aligns with Schrock-type carbenes rather than Fischer-type. Being a metallocene is not required for carbene chemistry, and a metal carbene is defined by a metal–carbon multiple-bond interaction rather than a free (unbound) carbene.

answer.text: Carbene carbon is electrophilic, commonly stabilized by heteroatom substituents, and associated with relatively low-valent metals
Carbene carbon is strongly nucleophilic, typically on early high-valent metals, and lacks π-acceptor stabilization
The complex must always be a metallocene (Cp2M)
The carbene carbon is always a free singlet carbene not bonded to a metal

questiontext.text: Fluxionality in organometallic complexes is most directly evidenced (and quantified) by:

generalfeedback.text: Fluxionality refers to rapid intramolecular rearrangements that can average distinct environments on the NMR timescale, and variable-temperature NMR can show coalescence and allow extraction of kinetic information. UV–Vis may change for many unrelated reasons and does not uniquely diagnose fluxional averaging of nuclear environments. Mass spectrometry and elemental analysis do not track rapid, reversible intramolecular rearrangements in solution on the relevant timescale.

answer.text: Variable-temperature NMR showing signal coalescence due to rapid intramolecular rearrangements
Only UV–Vis spectroscopy showing color change with time
Only mass spectrometry showing different isotopic patterns
Only elemental analysis showing changing percent composition

questiontext.text: In an oxidative addition step at a transition-metal center, the most typical changes are:

generalfeedback.text: Oxidative addition adds fragments (often two new ligands derived from one substrate) to the metal, commonly increasing the metal oxidation state and increasing the coordination number. A simultaneous decrease in oxidation state and coordination number corresponds more to reductive elimination than oxidative addition. The coordination number change is not inherently “+4,” and decreasing coordination number contradicts the defining feature of adding groups to the metal center in oxidative addition.

answer.text: Increase in metal oxidation state and increase in coordination number
Decrease in metal oxidation state and decrease in coordination number
No change in oxidation state, but coordination number increases by 4
Oxidation state increases, but coordination number must decrease

questiontext.text: A typical Ziegler–Natta catalyst system for alkene polymerization uses:

generalfeedback.text: Ziegler–Natta polymerization commonly uses a titanium halide (such as TiCl4) together with an alkylaluminum cocatalyst to generate active sites for stereospecific alkene insertion. The PdCl2/CuCl2-type system is characteristic of olefin oxidation chemistry rather than Ziegler–Natta polymerization. RhCl(PPh3)3 is best known as a homogeneous hydrogenation catalyst, and Fe(CO)5 is a metal carbonyl not used as the standard Ziegler–Natta catalyst pair. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/eecdaa56-93b9-4e87-bc04-9974af604151/inorganic_unit_07.txt)

answer.text: TiCl4 with an organoaluminum cocatalyst such as AlEt3
PdCl2 with CuCl as reoxidant
RhCl(PPh3)3 with H2
Fe(CO)5 with excess CO

questiontext.text: Using the neutral (covalent) electron-counting method, the total valence electron count at Fe in \(\mathrm{Fe(\eta^5\!-\!C_5H_5)(CO)_2CH_3}\) is:

generalfeedback.text: In neutral counting, Fe contributes 8 electrons (group 8 metal). The \(\eta^5\)-cyclopentadienyl ligand contributes 5 electrons, each CO contributes 2 electrons, and the methyl (alkyl) contributes 1 electron, giving \(8 + 5 + 2+2 + 1 = 18\). The 16-electron result typically comes from incorrectly treating Cp as a 6-electron donor in the neutral method or forgetting the alkyl contribution. The 17-electron result usually comes from dropping one electron contribution (often the alkyl) or mixing ionic and neutral conventions. The 20-electron result generally reflects double-counting the Cp donation or assigning incorrect electron donation numbers.

questiontext.text: The formal oxidation state of Mn in \(\mathrm{[Mn(CO)_5Br]}\) is:

generalfeedback.text: In oxidation-state assignment for organometallics, CO is treated as a neutral ligand, while bromide is treated as \(\mathrm{Br^-}\). Since the overall complex is neutral, the metal must balance the −1 charge from bromide, so Mn is +1. Assigning Mn as 0 incorrectly treats bromide as neutral, and +2 would require an additional anionic ligand or overall positive charge. A −1 oxidation state would require the ligand set to be net positive (not the case here).

questiontext.text: In an oxidative addition of \(\mathrm{H_2}\) to a 16-electron square-planar \(\mathrm{d^8}\) complex (typical late metal chemistry), the electron count at the metal center most commonly becomes:

generalfeedback.text: Oxidative addition adds two new metal–ligand bonds and typically increases both oxidation state and coordination number. In electron-counting terms, adding \(\mathrm{H_2}\) as two hydride ligands commonly increases the metal valence electron count by 2, converting a 16-electron species to an 18-electron species. A drop to 14 would correspond to ligand loss or reductive elimination-like behavior rather than oxidative addition. A final count of 20 would exceed the common 18-electron stability guideline for many low-spin organometallic complexes and usually indicates incorrect counting.

answer.text: 14 electrons
16 electrons
18 electrons
20 electrons

questiontext.text: A metal–alkyl complex \(\mathrm{M{-}CH_2CH_3}\) undergoes β-hydride elimination to give a metal hydride and an alkene. The alkene formed is:

generalfeedback.text: β-hydride elimination removes a hydrogen from the β-carbon (the carbon adjacent to the metal-bound carbon) and forms a C=C bond between the α and β carbons while generating \(\mathrm{M{-}H}\). For an ethyl ligand (\(\mathrm{-CH_2CH_3}\)), the α–β pair is exactly two carbons, so the resulting alkene is ethene (\(\mathrm{CH_2{=}CH_2}\)). Methane would correspond to protonation/hydrogenolysis, propene would require a three-carbon chain, and ethyne would require a different elimination pathway that creates a triple bond.

answer.text: Methane
Ethene
Propene
Ethyne

questiontext.text: Consider a metal carbonyl series where the metal oxidation state becomes more negative (more electron-rich metal center). The \(\nu_{\mathrm{CO}}\) stretching frequency in IR is expected to:

generalfeedback.text: Increased electron density at the metal generally enhances metal-to-CO π backbonding into CO π* orbitals, weakening the C–O bond. Weakening the internal C–O bond lowers the CO stretching frequency, so \(\nu_{\mathrm{CO}}\) decreases. An increase would be consistent with less backbonding and a stronger C–O bond, which contradicts the electron-rich metal premise. The number of CO ligands matters for patterns, but the frequency is strongly influenced by bonding (especially backbonding), and vibrational motion does not vanish upon coordination.

answer.text: Increase due to reduced backbonding
Decrease due to increased backbonding
Stay constant because \(\nu_{\mathrm{CO}}\) depends only on the number of CO ligands
Become zero because CO no longer vibrates

questiontext.text: In the Dewar–Chatt–Duncanson model, stronger metal→olefin π backdonation most directly leads to which change in the coordinated alkene?

generalfeedback.text: π backdonation populates the olefin π* orbital, reducing the C=C bond order and therefore lengthening the C=C bond. Reduced bond order typically lowers the C=C stretching frequency relative to the free alkene. Claiming “no change” ignores the central predictive value of the model for structure–bonding correlations in metal–olefin complexes. Formation of an alkane requires additional reaction steps (such as hydrogenation) and is not an automatic consequence of coordination alone.

answer.text: Shorter C=C bond and higher C=C stretching frequency
Longer C=C bond and lower C=C stretching frequency
No change in C=C bond length; only metal–carbon bonds change
Conversion of the alkene into an alkane without any reaction step

questiontext.text: A student proposes that in a catalytic cycle, “migratory insertion of CO into a metal–alkyl bond” directly forms:

generalfeedback.text: Migratory insertion of CO into a metal–alkyl bond inserts CO between the metal and the alkyl group, converting \(\mathrm{M{-}R}\) into an acyl linkage \(\mathrm{M{-}C(O)R}\). A metal–alkoxide would typically arise from insertion of an oxygen-containing molecule or from nucleophilic attack on a coordinated CO followed by further transformations, not the elementary CO insertion step itself. Metal hydride formation is more directly tied to steps like oxidative addition of \(\mathrm{H_2}\), β-hydride elimination, or hydride transfer processes. Metal carbenes are characteristic intermediates in carbene chemistry and metathesis, not the standard direct outcome of CO insertion into an alkyl bond.

answer.text: A metal–alkoxide (M–OR)
A metal–acyl (M–C(O)R)
A metal–hydride (M–H)
A metal–carbene (M=CR2)

questiontext.text: A complex shows two distinct ligand environments at low temperature in NMR, but only one averaged signal at higher temperature due to fluxionality. The temperature at which the two signals merge into one is called:

generalfeedback.text: Fluxional organometallic complexes can undergo rapid intramolecular rearrangements that average NMR environments on the NMR timescale. The specific temperature where two separate resonances merge into a single resonance is termed the coalescence temperature and is used along with models to estimate rate constants. Decomposition temperature is unrelated to dynamic exchange averaging, and melting/boiling points are bulk phase-change properties not defined by NMR line-shape behavior.

answer.text: Decomposition temperature
Coalescence temperature
Melting point
Boiling point

questiontext.text: In the Wacker-type Pd-catalyzed oxidation of an alkene, the role commonly attributed to \(\mathrm{CuCl_2}\) (or related copper salt) is to:

generalfeedback.text: In Pd-catalyzed olefin oxidation (Wacker-type chemistry), the palladium center cycles between Pd(II) and Pd(0), and a reoxidant is needed to regenerate Pd(II). Copper chloride is commonly used to reoxidize Pd(0) back to Pd(II), enabling turnover of the catalytic cycle. Copper salts are not the alkene source, do not primarily generate metathesis carbenes in this context, and do not function as a heterogeneous solid support in the typical homogeneous Wacker system.

answer.text: Act as the alkene source
Reoxidize Pd(0) back to Pd(II) in the catalytic cycle
Convert the alkene into a metal carbene for metathesis
Serve as the solid support for heterogeneous catalysis

questiontext.text: A Ziegler–Natta catalyst system is best described as a combination of:

generalfeedback.text: Ziegler–Natta polymerization is taught as a heterogeneous catalytic system where titanium-based halides are activated by organoaluminum cocatalysts to form active centers that insert alkenes and control stereochemistry (tacticity). Rhodium phosphine complexes are highlighted in homogeneous hydrogenation (Wilkinson-type) rather than Ziegler–Natta polymerization. Iron/cobalt surface catalysts align with Fischer–Tropsch syngas conversion, and ruthenium carbene complexes align with olefin metathesis catalysis rather than Ziegler–Natta insertion polymerization. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/eecdaa56-93b9-4e87-bc04-9974af604151/inorganic_unit_07.txt)

answer.text: A titanium halide and an alkylaluminum cocatalyst that generates active sites for olefin insertion polymerization
A rhodium phosphine complex used mainly for alkene hydrogenation
An iron or cobalt surface catalyst used mainly for syngas-to-hydrocarbon conversion
A ruthenium carbene complex used mainly for C=C bond metathesis
